• Please RSVP via Camille (+33670831699).
The Venue

Our wedding will take place at the venue 'Fôret', just 15 minutes outside the city, in the hills of Comasagua. With its spacious terrace, big garden, and breathtaking views, it felt like the perfect place to say yes and celebrate with you!

View on Google Maps
Wedding Party
Attire: Formal
Suits, ties, floor-length dresses, and gowns.

If wearing a dress or gown, we recommend a shawl or light jacket as it might get chilly at night.

Please keep the grass in mind when choosing shoes.

Civil Ceremony
The civil ceremony will take place at the same venue as the rest of the event, followed by a cocktail reception, dinner, and party.
Registry

Having you with us on our wedding day is the best gift! As our life is full of travel and changes, we’d be grateful for gifts that are mostly monetary, helping us make memories wherever life takes us next.

Pórtico Real Siman Zola
Getting Here
Airport
You should land at Aeropuerto Internacional Óscar Arnulfo Romero. Don’t worry, it’s the only international airport, so you’ll definitely arrive here! It’s about 45 minutes from San Salvador.

Getting to San Salvador
Taxi: Taxis Acacya are usually waiting outside the airport. Fare is around $30–35 USD. If you arrive late at night, it’s best to reserve in advance.
Book a shuttle service: Don Bosco Travel – Contact: +503 7820-5478. Fare is around $40. Just let them know you’re part of the “Le Roy y Villavicencio” wedding.

Hotels
Special discounts with the hotels below are available for our wedding guests

Airbnbs
If you prefer booking an Airbnb, we recommend searching in this area to stay close to the designated pick-up points for the wedding events.
Open in Google Maps
Keep in Mind
• Be sure to have a valid passeport.
• For E.U. citizen flying through the US: make sure you have a valid ESTA.
• The local currency is the US dollar.
• There is no vaccines required to enter El Salvador!
• El Salvador uses the same outlets as the US (Type A and Type B), bring an adaptor if needed.
Things to do in El Salvador


Our handpicked suggestions for exploring the country:

Day Trips

La Libertad Beaches: Just 45 mins from San Salvador

  • El Tunco: Go to any of the restaurants and bars around in the little surf town. Don’t miss the baos!
  • El Zonte: Take a surf lesson, skate in the bowl, or enjoy food and drinks at one of the restaurants/bars by the beach.
  • La Hola: Delicious seafood and drinks with great ocean view.
  • Puro Surf: Surf academy + restaurant. Try surf-skating if you feel adventurous.
  • Cascadas de Tamanique: About an hour away. Intermediate hike to stunning waterfalls. For a guide, contact Vladi (+503 7099 1445).

Centro Histórico de San Salvador: A mix of culture and fun

  • Play pool and eat choripanes in the old-fashioned bar La Dalia
  • Dance at Cha-Cha-Cha
  • Check out City Forum Binaes and the National Palace

Peñón de Comasagua: Small hike to a giant rock with awesome views

Cerro Verde: Nature and views

  • Hike the Volcán de Santa Ana if you’re up for it
  • Enjoy Volcán de Izalco from Casa 1800 (perfect spot for lunch or drinks)
  • Camp at Casa de Cristal for a night under the stars

Parque El Imposible: Tons of trails for hiking and exploring the Salvadorian jungle.



Overnight Trips

Beaches in Oriente:

  • El Cuco: Chill at La Tortuga for a full beach day.
  • Punta Mango: Visit the wildest and most beautiful beaches in the country. Take a surf lesson! (This is where we got engaged!)

Mirador Espíritu de la Montaña (Conchagua): Bring or rent a tent and enjoy a breathtaking sunrise with views stretching across El Salvador, Honduras, and Nicaragua.



Several Days Trip

If you dare venturing beyond the frontier of El Salvador, we highly recommend a visit to Antigua, Guatemala (~5 hours bus drive from San Salvador). For the ultimate adventure, hike Acatenango Volcano and spend an unforgettable overnight stay with an active volcano erupting right before your eyes.

Q & A
Where can I stay?
See the hotel recommendations — Airbnbs are also a good option. San Salvador has plenty of options to suit different budgets.

If you're staying at an Airbnb, consider areas like San Benito, Escalon, or Zona Rosa to be close to the designated pick-up zones.

What will the weather be like?
March is one of the warmest months of the year. In the mountains (like the venue), nights can get a little chilly, so pack a light sweater or jacket if you’re heading up there.

What clothes should I bring?
Think light and fresh: linen shirts, shorts, dresses. Don’t forget a swimsuit if you’re planning to hit the beach, lake, or waterfalls.

How can I move around?
The easiest way is by Uber or Taxis Acacya (a reliable local taxi service).

Is it safe?
Yes, El Salvador is now quite safe to visit! Just stay aware of your surroundings, like you would anywhere when traveling.

Where can I get my hair and/or makeup done?
Rouge
Phone: 7883 8680
Address: Avenida Revolución, Colonia San Benito #1, San Salvador, EL Salvador
Google Maps | Instagram
JR Studio
Phone: 7045 0464
Address: Calle La Mascota 940, San Salvador, El Salvador

Makeup at your location:
Andriana Rais: 7743 1518 – Instagram
Valeria Staben – Instagram

Are children invited?
With much love, we’ve decided to celebrate our wedding as an adults-only event. Thank you for your understanding.

Should I carry cash?
Yes, especially outside the city, there are places that don't take credit cards. In El Salvador, the currency is US dollars. You can find ATMs at the airport, banks and malls
